are to be seen the gyrus rectus, and the 
termination of the <s>se<\s> 2nd frontal convolution at the 
base of the brain. The tip of the lateral ventricle 
is just seen on the right side while on the left 
it has not yet come into view.
[The <u>tractus internus <\u> has now broken through the 
grey matter immediately below the gyrus fornicatus,
and has partly coalesced with that from the opposite side 
to form the genu of the corpus callosum. The union is 
not as yet complete, & it will be noticed that the 
central fibres of the genu are those wh: first coalesce.
The fibres in some cases run transversely across, in others 
slant upwards, some downwards. The fibres entering it 
on each side from the 1st, 2nd & 3d frontal convolutions 
are very numerous. The fibres from the 3d frontal, however,
are derived as will be the better seen afterwards <s>only from its upp <\s> completely or in great part from its upper 
half to two-thirds. The lower third to half of this convolution 
sends its fibres into the outer capsule. As the outer capsule has not 
yet appeared, however, in any of the illustrations mentioned <s>given <\s>,
further particulars must be reserved. The corpus 
callosum receives at this part few if any fibres from the 
gyrus fornicatus. The fibres from the upper border of this convolution (C1) <s>do run <\s>
appear to run into the corpus callosum, but those derived from the 
greater part of its extent (c.c) pass <s>enter <\s>  backwards not downwards 
into the common corpus callosum fibres. Many of its 
fibres are interconvolutional that is to say run between 
its different parts. The callosal fibres are always
